children.message:
It is mostly because of the capabilities of SONM over Golem. Golem for the longest time didn't have anything other than image rendering, and nothing with Docker. They were delayed heavily and took over a 6 month delay to release Brass Golem.

I think they saw Sonm and decided to rework it to be Docker based, at least I know they install docker and virtual box when you install the latest Golem.

But they still have only image rendering support. A year and a half of development and only image rendering.

SONM comes in, with only 3-4 months of development before the ICO, releases a Quake3 prototype during the ICO, and can already run anything docker can. I just think the SONM team is technically stronger than the Golem team and have already shown it.

There was a lot of FUD during the ICO and not so great PR handling from the SONM team which lead to misinformation and negative thoughts on SONM, but it has improved and it's the stronger product in my opinion.

I plan to do another article when they fix or add the environment variable stuff I mentioned.

817328629.message:
Ha! Yep, in full agreement with you there.

Though I've found it's more of a situation of a "programmer" feels comfortable in what he's using at the moment. It's the age old fight against change. Having done my CS degree in the 90's I went through the usual Pascal / C++ / Java and at the end thought: "Java seems to be the nicest thing to work in." Well, of those 3. Then my first real job was in Delphi, so the Pascal found its way back in my life, and I started thinking: "What was I on about with Java?" Later PHP, JavaScript, Python, VB, VBA, VB.Net, C#, etc. Much the same scenario applied, though I must say PHP gave me the same sic feeling as Perl, and to some measure C++, but that's due to it's enigma-code-like usage of strange and not-so-wonderful off-putting characters. Only after some years did I realize there's not much difference at all, except maybe for Lisp which I've had some dealings with since the late 80's. If I could find work which would allow me to use only Lisp, I'd drop everything else - but that's only because I can find everything I like in other languages are all combined in Lisp.

I feel a "programmer" needs to test as many languages as he can get his hands on - be that in his private time or not. Even if they're pigs, it might still give you ideas of how to go about coding in other (more mainstream) languages using more efficient / less verbose / more readable / easier managed / etc. coding concepts. I'm sure that if C programmers never looked at something like Symula, they'd never have thought to create C++ to add some OOP onto C. And if they never looked at Lisp (and its derivatives), then the recent functional stuff wouldn't even have been a consideration.

A caveat to this is there's no invention any more. For the past 50 years languages have been tweaked only. New languages were simply re-syntaxing of old stuff and combining ideas from various other ancestors. Nothing new has evolved since Lisp and Algol (the 2 extremes in "3rd" generation languages), perhaps Symula's OOP might be classed here, but it wasn't the first either. I.e. either from the maths side or from the physical switches side. Most languages try to find some balance between these two by taking parts from them, e.g. instead of Algol's conditional branches, C implemented the if-then-else idea from Lisp.

What I really want to see is something totally different. No new flavour on old stuff. But I realize this is something very difficult indeed.

Something I don't understand though: Why is everything still just through simple text? Why has there not been some truly "visual" language created based on something like GraIL. http://www.formfollowsfucki...

810422746.message:
The single biggest problem is that with the exception of Linux (and the BSDs) it's somewhat difficult to create and distribute a filesystem driver. Doing anything kernel level in Windows is always a nasty prospect (ugh, visual C++, kill me now, and that's without even mentioning the horror that is Microsofts standard libraries), and I know next to nothing about the internal architecture of OS X, but I'm sure doing anything there will involve the purchase of some pricey Apple hardware and signing up for a developer account of some kind just to access the API docs.

Given the above, is it really any suprise that support for alternative filesystems on OS X and Windows is in such a sorry state (slightly better on OS X, but that's mostly because OS X gets a lot of freebies from it's Unix heritage)?

It is unfortunate that NTFS has such poor performance in Linux, but as you point out, it's reverse engineered so the fact it works at all is amazing. That said, I still wouldn't want to use NTFS for anything as it has some less than desirable characteristics.

children.message:
UDF *doesn't* require a full drive on HDDs, only on pendrives (and this "restriction" only applies to Windows).

On standard removable devices you can get away with a single-partition or a full-drive FS (since Windows will not recognize beyond the first partition on these due to some really dumb artificial restriction imposed by MS - a "workaround" is to use GPT + Paragon GPT Loader... but this most likely will cause problems on anything post-XP). But on anything that identifies itself as an run-off-the-mill HDD, you NEED to have partitions.

The major problem with UDF is that it doesn't have a official partition ID (neither under MBR nor on GPT). But Microsoft "recommends" using 0x06 (VFAT) / 0x07 (NTFS) on MBR, and Microsoft Basic Data Partition on GPT. Any of these will allow your UDF partition to be recognized and mounted under XP/Vista/7/8.

Linux will accept anything that you throw at it (flat devices, MBRs, GPTs...), as it should be. Not sure about OSX since I don't deal with Macs.

810613249.message:
I've wondered this too but from a slightly different angle. I was after a filesystem format that has high limitations, e.g. filesystem size and file length, but a very simple layout and structure so that a driver for it is simple and can be ported widely including, for example, to small embedded environments, even if read-only there. To be cross-platform, I assumed native attributes would have to be as meta-data tags on a file. The simplicity would hit performance, e.g. files can't be fragmented, but then ease of implementation is valued over performance.

For your needs, plain UDF was the best hope I found. Does it matter Linux doesn't do beyond 2.01?

Why go trough the hassle of multiboot setups just for development environments?

You could just use one host with two VM's, if you are using multiple monitors just dedicate one monitor to a VM. You can even hook up an extra mouse and keyboard for the VM. On the host you can host a Samba share to share files between the machines.

If you need better disk performance from the VM, just use physical disks. When you are using physical disks you can even boot them natively when needed (if needed at all).

811053364.message:
UDF 2.01 is quite fine, it supports all the major features you need in a filesystem (unix permissions, hardlinks softlinks, metadata, >4GB files). Later revisions add features for optical media, which has no effect on the mode you use for random access devices. So it works quite well for USBs.

If you want to format it correctly, you need to zero your device, that is "dd if=/dev/zero of=/dev/device bs=512". Most OSs use magic bits to determine filesystems, and when you format as UDF some old FAT bits aren't touched (the danger of quick formats). So if you don't do a zero, then some devices may get confused. Next you need to invoke it like this "mkudffs --blocksize=512 --media-type=hd --utf8 --lvid=DriveLabel --vid=DriveLabel --fsid=DriveLabel /dev/device" (you don't need a partition table, especially since there is no UDF partition id, which confuses some OSs). That blocksize is rather important. Also note that you *must* unmount properly, especially in Windows, otherwise you can lose write support on windows. You need to mount it on linux to have write access again (something wrong with Windows' implementation?).

Now I must admit I haven't gotten this to work in OSX, but that is more not having one then anything. I'm pretty sure OSX has its own cli tool to format devices as UDF, which may be compatible with other OSs, but I can't try it.

811475178.message:
Not exactly correct about HFS only having R/O access. There are stuff like MacDrive which do allow write access to HFS from a windows OS: http://www.macwindows.com/d...

As for UDF, I've had nothing but issues using it. Mostly corruption of data, but also slow performance on some systems.

Alternatively, the VM idea could be used to "build your own NAS inside your PC". I.e. run some minimalist OS http://doc.freenas.org/inde... in a VM, then share a folder with the host OS. That way your Win/Mac could link to the Ext4/JFS/ZFS/etc. Linux file system of your choice, without needing any "drivers". That way the VM is simply your "driver" to the Linux FS, your host would still have decent performance for whatever else you have running on it. Also the connection speed is in essence even faster than 1G LAN connected NAS. Of course this is not a very simple thing to achieve - you'd need to map some physical discs / partitions onto the VM and link to it through a bridge-LAN, and your bootup virtual disc needs to be placed on something like a FAT32 (else your hosts can't get to it). But if performance and robustness is your goal, this is your best bet.

You're correct about the commercial NAS boxes being less than optimal. In my own experience I tend to get much better performance by simply default installing a FreeNAS onto an old PC than any commercial NAS I've tried. Never mind tweaking it to get even better performance. But you're still limited to the LAN speed and/or USB2 - why are there so few NASes with USB3 and 1GB LAN?

children.message:
Yep, you'll find that most (if not all) NAS boxes use the very least (and cheapest) hardware possible. Stuff like Atom CPU's are common place even on mid-range NASes. Then they'd also have extremely cut down motherboards, usually not even a SATA3 connection for the HDD/SSD. Then they usually have some Linux / BSD default installed with a bit of web-page front end of their own - for configuration. But usually they're not even software optimized. So I'd not expect too much from them. It's only in more "industrial" NASes where you could get some decent performance - especially with multiple users, but then your cost is going to sky-rocket. On the low-end scale (mine's an Iomega iConnect, so only allows 4x USB2 discs running on an Iomega branded Debian) I've seen max throughput of around 10MB/s (avg 6MB/s) - and if I plug that USB disc directly into a USB2 port I get around 35MB/s, so it's not the disc - it's the silly slow NAS. With that same disc in a USB3 port I get around 50-70 MB/s, so if the NAS had some decent hardware it "might" have performed adequately.

That's why I'm suggesting installing a FreeNAS as a Virtual Machine on Windows / Mac. That way you get the same performance as your own PC gives. A bit convoluted for sure, but at least it's a lot less time wastage than searching for drivers which may exist but only in beta form at best. I've just tried it for myself again, just to see how "difficult" / time consuming this idea is. Downloaded the newest FreeNAS iso, created a new VM in VirtualBox doing that exact same procedure as stipulated in the 2nd link in my previous post. Took me all of 30 min to setup to get a share working in Windows to a ZFS disc. Permissions was the biggest issue which needed some setting changes to the cifs share. Then another 1 min to setup a shortcut in the Startup menu to load that VM as a headless guest so it's available as soon as I login without me needing to click anything. Then I tested throughput using around 5GB of files to copy onto it, went at 65 MB/s, and copying off was 58MB/s - a LOT faster than the "commercial" NAS - and that's without me even trying to optimize the thing and only working through the VBox's virtual disc (which obviously slows things down as well, a RAW disc would perform at near max speed). If you don't like Oracle, then VMWare is also capable of doing the same, apparently - though I've not done it using VMWare.

Unfortunately FreeNAS only gives UFS/ZFS as file system for new blank discs, but most Linuxes could mount those natively. Or you could install another Linux and simply share from that if you really want to use something like ext4, but then the pre-setup might be a bit more geeky.

What I haven't done yet - which would be a definite MUST in your case would be to link a physical disc into that VM (i.e. RAW disc / partition). But that's quite possible through some cli: http://www.virtualbox.org/m...

One thing to remember though: your VDI files (i.e. the virtual discs) need to be on a FAT32 disc/partition so all your OSs can get to them easily. Fortunately FreeNAS needs only 4GB for its install disc - so the VDI would work on the FAT32.

858949007.message:
I was on the same situation - just upgraded to Windows 7, and got a 2TB external HDD. However, OSX isn't on my list of requirements. Did my experiments:

- FAT32: No way in hell. Once you add DVD9 ISOs and VM images, it quickly loses. Plus it has no POSIX permissions, no symlinks, heavy fragmentation... Just say NO.

- ext3: There are a couple of very good drivers for Windows, Ext2IFS and ext2fsd. Sure, you lose journaling, but still, both are very solid drivers that I had been using for ages in XP (good performance, rock-solid stability). Unfortunately, UAC ruins the party here: you lose the ability to run executables under Vista/7/8 (regular EXEs will work, but anything that requires elevation or admin privilegies -like installers, for example- will FAIL with a obscure error message related to network paths). No fix (except for disabling UAC which is a big NO-NO) because this behaviour is intentional by MS unless you stick to FAT/NTFS/UDF.

- UDF: Works wonders for small volumes. You lose XP write compatibility (only one driver was ever developed with write support for HDDs, SAI' WriteUDF! - it costs $89, and the company is now defunct, so if you still care about XP, better bite the bullet and buy a new PC). Unfortunately for large volumes (like my 2TB external), no filesystem check tool in this world will recognize it (tried with chkdsk and Solaris/OpenIndiana UDF fsck: both complain about the device having no filesystem). And no fsck under Linux means that if you care about data integrity you should not be using UDF. Oh, if your volume gets flagged as dirty, unfortunately Linux won't "unlock" it for Windows, only chkdsk will do... and it also means that since chkdsk won't deal with such large volumes (>1TB?), your FS ends tied to Linux anyway. Close, but no cigar. But for small devices (pendrives?), it's the way to go as long as you don't need XP write access.

- NTFS: Sure, write performance sucks for native SATA drive/controller pairs. But on USB-attached drives it doesn't matter at all which FS you do pick - write performance is pretty much equal between NTFS, ext3 and UDF (albeit CPU usage is MUCH higher with NTFS when combined with the highly-CPU-bound USB interface). Symlinks come for free if you're using Vista or later. UNIX/POSIX file permissions require a user mapping file for ntfs-3g, after adding it, it works pretty much as expected. Limited error checking support under Linux, but for mutliboot scenarios, it doesn't matter that much anyway as long as one OS agrees to check and fix your FS.

- exFAT: Is this a bad joke!?!??! Patent minefield, sucky drivers outside Windozeland, hyperpropietary specs... NO.

As usual, Microsoft is ruining the party. But I guess that I will settle with NTFS for the time being... And no, for home users with limited budgets and rational download/storage requirements, NAS is not the solution.

children.message:
Agreed. Quick-fix cheap solution which works reasonably well would be NTFS. If you can stay with USB discs and don't worry too much about permissions and/or indexing/journaling while not in Windows. And a decent NAS is definitely not a cheap thing at all (our company invested in an industrial one with 10TB storage Raid 5, cost an arm and a leg, but works like a charm, and fast as lightning).

But as I've stated another free alternative would be a NAS inside a VM inside each of your OS's. It's just not a quick-fix, but you can get near perfect performance with all the bells-n-whistles of a FS like ZFS (even stuff like snapshots to be able to roll-back to an earlier version of the file). It's just that you'd be giving up a bit of RAM and some CPU cycles.
